alert.note: Alert for Washington (Vermont) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Burlington (Northern Vermont and New York)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued July 10 at 10:40AM EDT until July 11 at 11:36PM EDT by NWS Burlington
info.description: ...Forecast flooding changed from Minor to Moderate severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Vermont... Winooski River At Waterbury affecting Washington County. For the Winooski River...including Waterbury...Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM THIS MORNING TO LATE TOMORROW EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Winooski River at Waterbury. * WHEN...From this morning to late tomorrow evening. * IMPACTS...At 419.0 feet, Water will flood fields behind the Vermont State Office Complex in Waterbury. Field flooding will occur from Waterbury downstream through Richmond. At 421.0 feet, Water will approach low lying parking lots at the Waterbury State Office complex, and Rowe Field in Waterbury will flood. Downstream in Richmond, Bridge Street at the Winooski bridge near the Round Church will be inundated, and the Richmond public park will flood. The river will be out of its banks from Waterbury downstream through Richmond, with considerable field flooding. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:15 AM EDT Monday the stage was 419.3 feet. - Bankfull stage is 419.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:15 AM EDT Monday was 419.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above moderate flood stage to 422.0 feet this afternoon and fall below flood stage Tuesday afternoon. - Flood stage is 419.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 420.6 feet on 07/02/2017. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued this evening at 1045 PM EDT.
